revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = KB | background = solo_singer | image = File:Kb-hga-img-12121.jpg | image_size = | birth_name = Kevin Elijah Burgess | alias = KB, K to the Second Letter | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1988|7|21|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[St. Petersburg, Florida]], United States | genre = [[Christian hip hop]] | occupation = [[Rapping|Rapper]], [[artists and repertoire|A&R executive]] | instrument = [[Voice]] | years_active =2006–present | label = [[Reach Records|Reach]], Native North | associated_acts = [[116 Clique]], HGA | website = {{URL|http://whoiskb.com}} }} '''Kevin Elijah Burgess''' (born July 21, 1988), better known by his stage name '''KB''', is an American [[Christian hip hop]] artist and [[music executive]] from [[St. Petersburg, Florida]]. He is the leader of the hip-hop group HGA, and was signed as a solo artist to [[Reach Records]] in 2010. He is also a member of the Reach Records-based hip-hop collective [[116 Clique]]. After releasing a [[mixtape]] in 2011 entitled ''Who Is KB?'', his debut album, ''[[Weight & Glory]]'', was released on July 17, 2012, to critical acclaim. On March 4, 2014 he released his first EP, ''100''. On April 21, 2015, he released his second album, ''[[Tomorrow We Live (album)|Tomorrow We Live]]''. October 20, 2017 was the release of his third album, ''[[Today We Rebel (album)|Today We Rebel]]''. == Biography == === Early life === Kevin Elijah Burgess was born in St. Petersburg, Florida on July 21, 1988,{{cite web|title=Amazing birthday by way of my lovely wife! |url=https://twitter.com/KB_HGA/status/491445999651815424|publisher=Twitter|author=KB official twitter account|accessdate=February 8, 2015|date=July 21, 2014}} into a military family.{{cite web|title=KB – Weight & Glory Behind the Music and More (@kb_hga @reachrecords)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vt69Gzf2IZM&feature=plcp|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=July 23, 2012|author=Reach Records|format=Video/Web|date=July 6, 2012}} Shortly after his birth his parents moved to [[Southern Illinois]] where he was raised for eight years. When he was 8 years old, his parents divorced and he moved back with his mother to the south-side of St. Petersburg, which according to Burgess is "probably one of the worst areas in the state." He did well in school and at age 15 was offered an opportunity to pursue college through a program called St. Petersburg Collegiate High School. But despite this opportunity, he struggled with extreme depression and experimented with various drugs to try to relieve it. He began struggling at school due to his problems with his personal life, and even contemplated suicide.{{cite web|title=KB|url=http://reachrecords.com/artists/show/KB|work=Reach Records Official Website|publisher=Reach Records|accessdate=July 23, 2012|author=Reach Records}} Jeremy offered him a CD, and Burgess says he was saved after hearing the [[Gospel]] presentation on the recording. ===Personal life=== Burgess is currently married with two children.{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/news/kb-is-breaking-the-christian-rap-mold|title=KB Is Breaking The Christian Rap Mold|work=The GRAMMYs|accessdate=March 8, 2015}} === Formation of HGA === After high school, Burgess enrolled in [[Bible college]] and befriended a group of Christian rappers and together they formed a hip hop group called HGA, short for His Glory Alone. HGA eventually caught the interest of [[Lecrae]], Ben Washer, and DJ Official, and were featured with [[Tedashii]] on the track "Go" from DJ Official's album ''Entermission''.{{cite web|title=Go – Tedashii|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/song/h-g-a/go/17698359|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media]]|accessdate=July 23, 2012|format=Web}}{{cite web|title=Entermission|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/entermission-mw0001787090|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=July 23, 2012}} Burgess was invited onto the “Acquire the Fire” tour by Lecrae, and was asked to join the [[Reach Records]] team just a few months later. === Signing with Reach Records === Burgess signed with Reach Records in 2010, and appeared that year on the album ''[[Rehab (Lecrae album)|Rehab]]'' by [[Lecrae]].{{cite web|title=Reach Records’ latest hip hop Artist KB, Makes July 17th Debut Release of ‘Weight & Glory’|url=http://breathecast.christianpost.com/articles/3753/20120717/christian-music-news-christian-hip-hop-news-kb-reach-records-kb-weight-glory.htm|work=Breathecast|publisher=[[Christian Post]]|accessdate=July 24, 2012|author=Rogers and Cowan PR|date=July 17, 2012}} His mixtape ''Who is KB?'' followed a year later, as did appearances with [[Derek Minor|PRo]] and Tedashii.{{cite web|title=PRo "116" feat. KB|url=http://rapzilla.com/rz/music/2835-pro-q116q-feat-kb|work=[[Rapzilla]]|accessdate=July 24, 2012|date=January 25, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Monger|first=James Christopher|title=Blacklight|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/blacklight-mw0002150464|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=July 24, 2012}}{{cite web|title=PRo 'Dying To Live' Tracklisting|url=http://rapzilla.com/rz/news/38-backstage/3420-pro-dying-to-live-tracklisting|work=[[Rapzilla]]|accessdate=July 24, 2012|date=August 2, 2011}} ''Who is KB?'' garnered 30,000 downloads by the following year. His first single, "Hello", featured Suzy Rock and was released in October 2011.{{cite web|title=KB "Hello" feat. Suzy Rock|url=http://rapzilla.com/rz/music/3758-kb-qhelloq-featuring-suzy-rock|work=[[Rapzilla]]|accessdate=July 24, 2012|date=October 28, 2011}} In January 2012, a second single, "Zone Out" featuring [[Chris Cobbins|Chris Lee Cobbins]], was released.{{cite web|title=KB "Zone Out" feat. Chris Lee|url=http://rapzilla.com/rz/music/freemp3s/4085-kb-zone-out|work=[[Rapzilla]]|accessdate=July 24, 2012|date=January 24, 2011}} Burgess then made an appearance with [[Andy Mineo]] on the [[Trip Lee]] album ''[[The Good Life (Trip Lee album)|The Good Life]]''. A third single by Burgess, "Go Off", featured Tedashii and Andy Mineo, and was released in June.{{cite web|title=KB "Go Off" ft. Andy Mineo & Tedashii|url=http://rapzilla.com/rz/music/4600-kb-go-off|work=[[Rapzilla]]|accessdate=July 24, 2012|date=June 7, 2012}} The following month, his debut album ''[[Weight & Glory]]'' was released.{{cite web|last=Ham|first=Robert|title=KB: Weight & Glory|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2012/julyweb-only/weight-and-glory.html|work=[[Christianity Today]]|publisher=Christianity Today|accessdate=July 19, 2012|date=July 17, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Peterson|first=Aaron|title=KB {{!}} Weight & Glory|url=http://thechristianmanifesto.com/archives/music-review/weight-and-glory|work=The Christian Manifesto|accessdate=July 19, 2012|format=Web|date=July 3, 2012}} On May 30, 2013, Reach announced a four-part project entitled "1st & 16th". This project would consist of Burgess releasing a new song every first and sixteenth of June and July. On June 1, Part 1, ''HCB Freestyle'' was released.{{cite web|url=http://reachrecords.com/blog/post/KB-x-1st-And-16th- |title=Reach Records |publisher=Reach Records |date=May 30, 2013 |accessdate=June 13, 2013}} The songs ''Ride'' and ''Be All Right'' were also part of the 1st and 16th project. On February 10, 2014, KB announced his new project, an EP entitled ''100'', which was released on March 4, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://reachrecords.com/releases/show/100 |title=Reach Records |publisher=Reach Records |date= |accessdate=May 12, 2014}} Burgess appeared in [[Family Force 5]] music video for the song "BZRK", released on May 23, 2014, on which Burgess is a featured artist.{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=au7of6Bd47Q|title = Family Force 5 - BZRK [feat. KB] (Official Music Video) |date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = May 23, 2014|website = [[YouTube]]|publisher =[[Google]] }} On February 3, 2015, KB took to social media to reveal his second studio album, ''Tomorrow We Live'', along with the cover and release date. It's scheduled to be released on April 21, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.rapzilla.com/rz/news/38-backstage/10012-kb-announces-new-2015-album-title-and-release-date|title=KB reveals new 2015 album title, cover and release date|author=David Daniels|work=Rapzilla|accessdate=February 6, 2015}} The first single off the album "Sideways" featuring Lecrae was released on February 23, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.rapzilla.com/rz/videos/10223-lyric-video-kb-sideways-feat-lecrae|title=Lyric Video: KB - Sideways feat. Lecrae|author=David Daniels|work=Rapzilla|accessdate=March 8, 2015}} The second single "Crowns & Thorns (Oceans)" was released on March 10, 2015.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} On October 20, 2017, KB released his third studio album ''Today We Rebel''.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/ca/album/today-we-rebel/id1282529229|title=Today We Rebel by KB on Apple Music|website=itunes.apple.com|accessdate=November 15, 2017}} The first single off the album "Tempo" was released a year prior to the album's release date.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/ca/album/tempo-single/id1134957982|title=Tempo - Single by KB on Apple Music|website=itunes.apple.com|accessdate=November 15, 2017}} The second single off the album "Monster" featuring [[Aha Gazelle]] was released on September 15, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://rapzilla.com/rz/music/16137-kb-monster-ft-aha-gazelle|title=Music: KB - Monster ft. Aha Gazelle|first=Steven|last=Solis|publisher=|accessdate=November 15, 2017}} == Discography == === Studio albums === {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"|Year ! rowspan="2"|Title ! colspan="7"|Chart positions |- ! style="width:60px;"|[[Billboard 200|US]]
{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/music/kb/chart-history/billboard-200|title=KB Chart History: Billboard 200|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} ! style="width:60px;"|US Gospel
{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/music/kb/chart-history/gospel-albums|title=KB Chart History: Gospel Albums|work=Billboard|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} ! style="width:60px;"|[[Top Christian Albums|US Christ.]]
{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/music/kb/chart-history/christian-albums|title=KB Chart History: Christian Albums|work=Billboard|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} ! style="width:60px;"|[[Top Independent Albums|US Ind.]]
{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/music/kb/chart-history/independent-albums|title=KB Chart History: Independent Albums|work=Billboard|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} ! style="width:60px;"|[[Top Rap Albums|US Rap]]

[[File:Аманкулова.jpg|thumb]] '''Kalima Amankulova''' (born 1915)<ref name=women>{{cite web|title=Women Leaders in the Former Soviet Union|url=http://www.guide2womenleaders.com/former_ussr.htm|work=Worldwide Guide to Women in Leadership|accessdate=13 January 2013|date=20 January 2008}}</ref> was a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Kyrgyz people|Kyrgyzstanian]] [[politician]]. She was [[Chairman of the Supreme Soviet]] of the [[Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic]] in 1938.<ref name="women" /><ref>{{cite web|last=Schemmel|first=B.|title=Soviet Republics|url=http://rulers.org/sovrep.html#kyrgyzstan|work=Rulers|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref> Her office as Chairman of the Supreme Soviet nominally made her "Head of the Republic".<ref name=1900s>{{cite web|title=Women in Power: 1900-1940|url=http://www.guide2womenleaders.com/womeninpower/Womeninpower1900.htm|work=Worldwide Guide to Women in Leadership|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Politics of Kyrgyzstan]]

{{Infobox person |name = Kamal Khalil |image = Kamal Khalil.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = Kamal Khalil addressing a crowd in the [[Tahrir Square]] |birth_name = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = [[Egypt]]ian |known_for = |alma_mater = |employer = |parents = |relations = |children = Omnia Khalil, Amal Khalil |party = [[Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)|Revolutionary Socialists]],
[[United Revolutionary Front]]{{Cite news |title=Revolutionary and leftist parties protest Constituent Assembly|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/revolutionary-and-leftist-parties-protest-constituent-assembly|agency=Egypt Independent|date=22 September 2012|accessdate=2012-12-04}}
[[Workers and Peasants Party (Egypt)|Workers and Peasants Party]] |footnotes = }} '''Kamal Khalil''' ({{lang-ar|كمال خليل}}, {{IPA-arz|kæˈmæːl xæˈliːl|IPA}}) is an [[Egyptians|Egyptian]] engineer and [[trade union|labour]] activist. He is a leading member of the [[Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)|Revolutionary Socialists]],{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/401570 | title=Labor activists organize despite legal hurdles | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | date=15 April 2011 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} a representative of the [[Workers Democratic Party]]{{cite web | url=http://bikyamasr.com/wordpress/?p=32778 | title=Fight for factories: Egypt’s textile workers challenge privatization | publisher=Bikya Masr | date=20 April 2011 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} and the founder{{cite web |url = http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2003/627/eg3.htm |title = Preempting activism |publisher = Al-Ahram |date = 27 February 2003 |accessdate = 4 May 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110404072628/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2003/627/eg3.htm |archivedate = 4 April 2011 |df = }} and director of the [[Center for Socialist Studies]] in [[Cairo]].{{cite web | url=http://www.arabawy.org/2010/04/04/protest/ | title=Abdel Quddos and Kamal Khalil | publisher=3arabawy | date=4 April 2010 | accessdate=24 May 2011 }} He is a critic of the [[List of political parties in Egypt#The known parties of Egypt|social democrats]], [[List of political parties in Egypt#The known parties of Egypt|youth parties]] and the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] in the post-[[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak]] Egypt.{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/04/20114221812915532.html | title=Empowering Egypt's workers revolution | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=25 April 2011 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} He advocates more [[proletariat|worker]]s' unity, particularly in regions such as [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]], which has in the past been a center of industrial struggle by [[2008 Egyptian general strike|textile workers]].{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9450/Egypt/Politics-/Textile-workers-unite-to-push-through-Shebin-ElKom.aspx | title=Textile workers unite to push through Shebin El-Kom demands | publisher=Ahram Online | date=6 April 2011 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} Khalil has said Egypt's workers must create independent trade unions and a political party to represent them: "No party will represent the workers other than the workers' party itself."{{cite web | url=http://mrzine.monthlyreview.org/2011/hanna020511.html | title=Egypt's Workers Keep the Revolution Alive | publisher=MR Zine | date=May 2, 2011 | accessdate=May 24, 2011 }} Prior to the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]], Khalil had been arrested many times. In 2003, he was arrested by the [[State Security Investigations Service]] (SSI) and placed in solitary confinement for his role in the [[Opposition to the Iraq War|anti-war movement]], causing the [[Stop the War Coalition]] in [[United Kingdom|Britain]] to demonstrate outside the [[Egyptian Embassy, London|Egyptian Embassy]] in [[London]]. ==See also== * [[Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)|Revolutionary Socialists]] * [[Workers Democratic Party]] * [[Center for Socialist Studies]] ==External links== * [http://www.3eyonelkalam.blogspot.com/ Eyes speak] Kamal Khalil's blog (Arabic) * [https://twitter.com/kamalkhalil20 Kamal Khalil's Twitter account] == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Khalil, Kamal}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Egyptian democracy activists]] [[Category:Egyptian dissidents]] [[Category:Egyptian human rights activists]] [[Category:Egyptian revolutionaries]] [[Category:Egyptian Trotskyists]] [[Category:People of the Egyptian revolution of 2011]] [[Category:Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)]] [[Category:Egyptian trade unionists]]

revision.comment: wl
revision.text:
This is a list of the major royal families and their allies in the [[Arabian Peninsula]] in the 20th century. * [[House of Saud|Al Saud]], became dominant through an alliance with the [[Salafi]]s. Now rules [[Saudi Arabia]]. * [[House of Rashīd]], (Al Rasheed) the House of Rasheed were a historic Arabian dynasty ruling between 1836–1921. * [[Al ash-Sheikh]], Saudi Arabia's leading religious family. * [[Hashemite]], evicted from Saudi Arabia in 1926 but moved to the north and controlled [[Iraq]] until 1958 and still controls [[Jordan]]. * [[House of Al-Sabah|Al-Sabah]], the rulers of [[Kuwait]]. * [[House of Thani|Al Thani]], the rulers of [[Qatar]]. * [[House of Khalifah|Al Khalifah]], the rulers of [[Bahrain]]. * [[House of Al-Falasi|Al-Falasi]] from [[Bani Yas]], the rulers of the [[United Arab Emirates]] and the Emirs of [[Dubai]] descend from this tribe. * [[House of Al Qasimi|Al Qasimi]], formerly known as Al Qawasim tribe, the rulers of [[Sharjah (emirate)|Sharjah]] and [[Ras Al Khaimah]] descend from this line. * [[Al Nuaimi|Al Nuaimi,]] the rulers of [[Ajman]] descend from this line. * [[Al Maktoum]], the rulers of Dubai descend from this line. * [[Al Mualla]], the rulers of [[Umm al Quwain]] descend from this line. * [[Al Sharqi]], the rulers of [[Fujairah]] descend from this line. * [[House of Al Bu Said|Al Bu Said]], the rulers of [[Oman]] descend from this line. * [[House of al Saeed]], one of the two current royal families in Oman.
==See also== * [[Tribes of Arabia]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Arab groups]] [[Category:Lists of families|Arabian houses]]

page.title: List of Knights of St Patrick

revision.comment: /* Further reading */
revision.text:
[[File:Insignia of Knight of St Patrick.jpg|thumb|right|200px|An illustration of the insignia of a Knight of St Patrick]] The Most Illustrious [[Order of Saint Patrick]] is a British [[order of chivalry]] associated with Ireland. The Order was created in 1783<ref name="royal">{{cite web |url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/output/page4880.asp |title=Monarchy Today: Queen and Public: Honours: Order of St Patrick |accessdate=2008-12-15 |work=Official website of the British Monarchy }}</ref> by [[George III of the United Kingdom|George III]] at the instigation of the [[Lord Lieutenant of Ireland]], [[George Nugent-Temple-Grenville, 1st Marquess of Buckingham|The 3rd Earl Temple]] (1753–1813; created The 1st [[Marquess of Buckingham]] in 1784). The regular creation of knights of Saint Patrick lasted until 1921, when most of Ireland became independent as the [[Irish Free State]].<ref name="royal"/> While the Order technically still exists, no knight of St Patrick has been created since 1936, and the last surviving knight, [[Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester]], died in 1974.<ref name="royal"/> [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|The Queen]], however, remains the Sovereign of the Order. The position of King of Arms of the order was held by Ulster King of Arms; this office still exists, since 1943 it has been combined with Norroy King of Arms. [[Saint Patrick|St Patrick]] is [[patron saint|patron]] of the order; its motto is ''[[Quis separabit?]]'',<ref name="royal"/> [[Latin]] for "Who will separate us?": an allusion to the [[Vulgate]] translation of [[Epistle to the Romans|Romans]] 8:35, "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ?"<ref>According to Galloway (pp 171–2), the motto was borrowed from the [[Order of the Friendly Brothers of St Patrick]], but was also appropriate politically in expressing a desire for unity</ref>
The first appointments were made on 11 March 1783, and consisted of 15 Knight Founders, and in total there have been 145 appointments. The original Royal Warrant (dated 5 February 1783) specified that there were to be no more than fifteen knights of the Order at any one time, something that changed in 1821 when [[George IV of the United Kingdom|George IV]] appointed an extra six knights (although the royal warrant was not altered to reflect this change until 1830).<ref name="lr">{{cite web|url=http://www.leighrayment.com/orders/patrick.htm|title=Leigh Rayment: Knights of St.Patrick|last=Rayment|first=Leigh|publisher=Leigh Rayment|date=24 April 2008|accessdate=2008-12-15}}</ref> [[William IV of the United Kingdom|William IV]] appointed an additional four knights at his coronation, and on 24 January 1833 increased the maximum number of knights to 22.<ref name="lr"/>

revision.text:
'''Maria Roda''' (1877–1958) was an Italian American [[anarchist]]-[[feminist]] activist, speaker and writer, who participated in the [[labour movement|labor struggles]] among [[textile industry|textile workers]] in [[Italy]] and the [[United States]] during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
==Early life== Born in 1877 in [[Como]], Italy, Maria Roda was an activist in radical social movements from a young age. Her mother, Adele Parravicini, died when Roda was young, leaving her and her three sisters in the care of their father, Cesare Roda Balzarini, a weaver and activist in the local anarchist-inspired labor movements. After her mother's death, Roda and her sisters worked in the [[silk|silk mills]] of Como. It was through the influence of her radical father and the contacts she made at the mills that she became an anarchist.<ref>Jennifer Guglielmo, ''Living the Revolution: Italian Women's Resistance and Radicalism in New York City, 1880-1945'' (Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press, 2010), p. 157</ref> The Italian government considered Cesare Roda to be one of the main anarchists in Como with connections to others in the movement abroad, and they monitored his activities and those of Maria throughout the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
== Early arrest and trial == In 1891, Maria Roda was arrested and sent to prison for three months for her involvement in a labor strike in [[Milan]]. Roda had been accused of inciting the strikers to riot against the police.<ref name = "daxa">{{Cite web | last = d'Axa | first = Zo |others=Mitch Abidor (trans.) | title = Little Girls | work = Marxists.org | accessdate = 2014-10-26 | date = 1895 | url = http://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/zo-daxa/1895/little-girls.htm }}</ref> She became famous among European activists for her spirit and her willingness to speak her mind. Even though she was only fourteen years old, she received this harsh sentence because of her defiant attitude towards the judge. When questioned about her role in inciting the riot by taunting a police officer, she said, "I pity [that] guard. I pity him because he barely earns his bread, because he's a poor devil. But it impresses me to see him go after other poor devils, his brothers...let him think about this."<ref name = "daxa" />
==Activism in Italian American anarchist movement== The Roda family immigrated to the United States in 1893 when Maria was 17. They settled in [[Paterson, New Jersey]], and quickly became active in the anarchist milieu there through one of the largest and more influential anarchist groups in the United States, [https://books.google.com/books?id=lOXr4cSzXL0C&lpg=PA178&ots=yv8i3oIolU&dq=Gruppo%20Diritto%20all'Esistenza&pg=PA178#v=onepage&q=Gruppo%20Diritto%20all'Esistenza&f=false Gruppo Diritto all'Esistenza] (Right to an Existence Group). Frustrated by the marginalization of women within the movement, Maria Roda and a few of the other activist women (including [[Ninfa Baronio]] and [[Ernestina Cravello]]) formed the Gruppo Emancipazione della Donna (Women's Emancipation Group) in 1897, so women in the anarchist movement could meet on their own and develop their own theories and methods of revolutionary working-class activism. As a result, Maria Roda and dozens of other women wrote, published and circulated anarchist-feminist writing through this and similar women's groups. Two of Roda's essays were published in ''La Questione Sociale'' (the Italian-language anarchist newspaper that was published in Paterson): "Alle operaie" (To women workers), September 15, 1897, and "Alle Madri" (To mothers), September 7, 1901.<ref>Jennifer Guglielmo, ''Living the Revolution: Italian Women's Resistance and Radicalism in New York City, 1880-1945'' (Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press, 2010), pp. 139, 162-72; Salvatore Salerno, "'No God, No Master': Italian Anarchists and the IWW" in Cannistraro and Meyer, eds., ''The Lost World of Italian American Radicalism'' (Prager, 2003).</ref>
==Roda and Emma Goldman== [[Emma Goldman]] first heard Maria Roda give a speech at a large rally in 1894 at the [[Bowery Theatre|Thalia Theater]] in Manhattan, which celebrated Goldman's release from prison. Although it was in Italian and Goldman understood none of it, she wrote in her memoir how she was moved by Roda's charismatic presence. Goldman wrote, "Maria's strange beauty and the music of her speech roused the whole assembly to tensest enthusiasm. Maria proved a veritable ray of sunlight to me." She then pledged to become Maria Roda's "teacher, friend, comrade."<ref>Emma Goldman, ''Living My Life: Volume 1'' (Unabridged) (ReadaClassic.com, 2010), p. 150.</ref>
==Roda and Pedro Esteve== Roda's lifelong partner was Pedro Esteve, a [[Catalonia|Catalan]] anarchist, printer, typesetter, and newspaper editor who helped to establish ''La Questione Sociale'', one of the main Italian language anarchist newspapers in the US.<ref>Carolyn P. Boyd, "The Anarchists and Education in Spain, 1868-1909", ''The Journal of Modern History'', Vol. 48, No. 4, (Dec., 1976), pp. 125-170; Chris Ealham, ''Class, Culture and Conflict in Barcelona, 1898-1937'' (Routledge, 2005)</ref> When Esteve was editor of ''La Questione Sociale'', from 1899 to 1906, women's writing was at its peak in the paper.<ref>Jennifer Guglielmo, ''Living the Revolution: Italian Women's Resistance and Radicalism in New York City, 1880-1945'' (Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press, 2010), 159.</ref> While Roda and Esteve were based in Paterson until at least 1908, they also lived in [[Tampa, Florida]], [[Brooklyn]], and [[Weehawken, New Jersey]], to spread the cause and organize other marginalized workers. Their home at 611 Gregory Avenue in Weehawken was often a center of radical activism through the 1930s, with large gatherings on Sundays. They had ten children, though only eight survived to adulthood (Violet, Sensitiva, Sirio, Iris, Flora, Pedro, Helios and Zephyr); they lost their ten-year-old son in an explosion that they believed was an attempt on Esteve's life.<ref>Paul Avrich, ''Anarchist Voices: An Oral History of Anarchism in America'', pp. 210-12, 143, 393</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Additional resources== *Jennifer Guglielmo, ''Living the Revolution: Italian Women's Resistance and Radicalism in New York City, 1880-1945.'' Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press, 2010. *Jennifer Guglielmo, "Transnational Feminism's Radical Past: Lessons from Italian Immigrant Women Anarchists in Industrializing America." ''Journal of Women's History'' 22.1 (2010): 10-33. [http://muse.jhu.edu/ Project MUSE]. *Donna R. Gabaccia, and Franca Iacovetta, eds, ''Women, Gender and Transnational Lives: Italian Workers of the World'' (University of Toronto Press, 2002). {{ISBN|0802084621}}. *Laura E. Ruberto, ''Gramsci, Migration, and the Representation of Women's Work in Italy and the U.S.'' (Rowman & Littlefield, 2009). {{ISBN|0739144324}} *Marcella Bencivenni, ''Italian Immigrant Radical Culture: The Idealism of the Sovversivi in the United States, 1890-1940'' (NYU Press, 2011). {{ISBN|0814723187}} *Salvatore Salerno, "[http://libcom.org/history/patersons-italian-anarchist-silk-workers-politics-race-salvatore-salerno Paterson's Italian Anarchist Silk Workers and the Politics of Race]" *Gary Mormino and George Pozzetta, ''The Immigrant World of Ybor City: Italians and their Latin Neighbors in Tampa, 1885-1985'' (University of Illinois Press, 1987). {{ISBN|978-0-8130-1630-6}} *Frances H. Nichols, "The Anarchists in America," New Outlook (August 10, 1901): 859-863 *Patrizia Sione, "Industrial Work, Militancy, and Migration of Northern Italian Workers in Europe and Paterson, New Jersey, 1880-1913" (PhD dissertation, State University of New York, Binghamton, 1992) *Philip V. Cannistraro, and Gerald Meyer, eds., ''The Lost World of Italian American Radicalism: Politics, Labor, and Culture'' (Greenwood Publishing Group, 2003). {{ISBN|0275978915}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Roda, Maria}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:People from Como]] [[Category:Writers from Paterson, New Jersey]] [[Category:Italian anarchists]] [[Category:American anarchists]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Textile workers]] [[Category:1877 births]] [[Category:Anarcha-feminists]]

revision.text:
[[File:MOD Guard Service Dog Handler MOD 45152255.jpg|thumb|A Ministry of Defence Guard Service (MGS) dog handler and his charge, [[Army Air Corps (United Kingdom)|Army Air Corps]] station at [[Middle Wallop]].]] The '''Ministry of Defence Guard Service''' ('''MGS''') is part of the [[Defence Infrastructure Organisation]] of the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]], and provides military establishments across the [[United Kingdom]] with unarmed [[security guard]]s and patrol services.<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/guidance/mod-guard-service MOD Guard Service], GOV.UK. Retrieved 8 November 2015.</ref>
The MGS deals with access and pass control, key control, vehicle and personnel searching, security patrols of buildings and [[perimeter fence]]s, dog patrols, [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]], and alarm monitoring. It also performs other duties like helicopter marshalling, first aid provision, mail and baggage scanning, security sweeps, and health and safety guidance.<ref name=Mod>http://www.mod.uk [http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/AboutDefence/WhatWeDo/SecurityandIntelligence/MDPGA/MinistryOfDefenceGuardServicemgs.htm MGS Page at MoD website] Retrieved 16 March 2012</ref>
The MGS works alongside armed guard services—the [[Military Provost Guard Service]] in England, Scotland and Wales, and the [[Northern Ireland Security Guard Service]] in Northern Ireland.
==History== From 2004 to 2013 MGS and [[Ministry of Defence Police]] worked in the [[Ministry of Defence Police and Guarding Agency]]. In April 2013, the MDPGA was disbanded and the MGS joined the [[Defence Infrastructure Organisation]].
==Uniforms and equipment==
Although the MGS are an unarmed security-officer organisation; they wear a similar uniform to police forces. This consists of (in an everyday working environment) a white shirt, tie, NATO-type navy blue jumper, high visibility jacket and a black peaked cap. The shirts and jumpers have epaulettes with "MOD GUARD SERVICE" or "MOD SECURITY" printed on them and the same on jackets. The black peaked cap has the MGS badge on the front and can be worn with a clear or black waterproof cover for use in wet weather.
Any equipment carried will consist of a radio, torch, first aid kit, search equipment, security-infringement paperwork, fire safety management plans, notebook and pen.
==See also== * [[Ministry of Defence Police]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/AboutDefence/WhatWeDo/SecurityandIntelligence/MDPGA/MinistryOfDefenceGuardServicemgs.htm}}
[[Category:Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)]] [[Category:Security organizations]] [[Category:Security guards]]
{{UK-gov-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Mohamed Haleem | image = | image_size = 300px | caption = Kesto Near Jumhooree Maidhan on 11 March 2011 | birth_date = {{birth date|1964|9|14|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Malé]], [[Maldives]] | other_names = Kesto | known_for = Founding [[Muscle load]] Gymnasium, co-founder BBFM | occupation = Entrepreneur | height = 5 ft. 11 in. | spouse = {{marriage|Mariyam Shaira|1983}} | children = Rizwana Mohamed Haleem (January 18, 1984)
Shaddad Mohamed Haleem (October 1, 1991)
Shaadhoon Mohamed Haleem (October 8, 1993) | website = [http://www.muscleload.com www.muscleload.com] }} '''Mohamed "Kesto" Haleem''', ([[Dhivehi language|Dhivehi]]: މުޙައްމަދު ހަލީމް )(born September 14, 1964), is the founder of [[Muscle load]] Gymnasium and the co-founder of [[BodyBuilding Federation of Maldives]](BBFM). He is a [[Maldives|Maldivian]] entrepreneur well known for the introduction of [[Bodybuilding]] in [[Maldives]]. ==Biography== Mohamed Haleem, (September 14, 1964) is the founder of [[Muscle load]] Gymnasium. He opened his personal gymnasium to the public in 1993. In 1997, Mohamed Haleem's father and his friend M W Deen founded the [[Bodybuilding Federation of Maldives]] (BBFM). Kesto, replaced his father as the Vice-Chairman of the BBFM after his death in 2001. Mohamed Haleem is a founder member of: *Bodybuilding Federation of Maldives[http://maldivesbodybuilding.org/ Body Building Federation of Maldives] *Commonwealth Bodybuilding federation *South Asian Bodybuilding and fitness Federation[http://www.sabbf.org/ South Asian Bodybuilding and Fitness Federation] *World Bodybuilding and Physique Sports Federation.[http://www.wbpsf.org/ World Bodybuilding and Physique Sports Federation] And Also a member of Asian Body Building Federation.[http://www.abbf.asia/16012010.html Asian Body Building Federation] ===Early life=== Haleem began his education at Montessori School, Malé. He then joined [[Majeediyya School]] to complete his secondary education. Haleem worked as a Deputy Immigration Officer of Maldives for 13 years. ==Awards== *Certificate of Merit (IFBB) for promoting Bodybuilding and Fitness among Maldivians *Bronze Medal (IFBB) for promoting Bodybuilding and Fitness among Maldivians[http://www.ifbb.com/reports/2000congress/bronze.html Bronze Medal for Promotion Bodybuilding and fitness among Maldivians from Ben Weider] from [[Ben Weider]] *Silver Medal (IFBB) for promoting Bodybuilding and Fitness among Maldivians *Silver Medal (IFBB) for promoting Bodybuilding and Fitness among South Asian region from [[Paul Chua]] *ABBF 50th Anniversary Diamond pin ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * https://about.me/kesto * [http://www.muscleload.com Muscle Load Official Website] for interest in bodybuilding, health and fitness *http://www.haveeru.com.mv/english/details/1133/Maldives_bodybuilders_beef_up_with_three_silvers_ {{DEFAULTSORT:Haleem, Mohamed}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Bodybuilders]] [[Category:Maldivian Muslims]] [[Category:Maldivian people]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

{{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox First Lady |honorific-prefix = [[Excellency|Her Excellency]] |name = Mama Ngina Kenyatta |image name = |imagesize = |order = 1st |office = First Lady of Kenya |term_label=In role |term_start = 12 December 1964 |term_end = 28 August 1978{{smallsup|1}} |president = |predecessor = Position established |successor = [[Lucy Kibaki]] |birth_date = 24 June 1933 (age 85) |birth_place = Ngenda, Kiambu District, Central Province, [[Kenya Colony]] |birthname = Ngina Muhoho |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Kenya]]n |party = [[Kenya African National Union|KANU]] |spouse = [[Jomo Kenyatta]] (m. 1951) |relations = |children = Christine Wambui (born 1953)
[[Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta]] (born 1961)
Anna Nyokabi Muthama née Kenyatta (also known as Jeni)
Muhoho Kenyatta |residence = [[Nairobi]], Kenya |alma_mater = |profession = |blank1 = Religion |data1 = Roman Catholicism |website = |footnotes = 1. Ngina retained her First Lady status even after the death of her husband in 1978. Incoming President [[Daniel arap Moi]] had separated from his wife in 1974. }} '''Ngina Kenyatta''' (born 24 June 1933), popularly known as "'''Mama Ngina'''", is the former [[First Lady of Kenya]]. She is the widow of the country's first president, [[Jomo Kenyatta]] (~1889–1978), and also the mother of President [[Uhuru Kenyatta]]. ==Biography== Mama Ngina was born Ngina Muhoho to Chief Muhoho wa Gathecha and [[Anne Nyokabi Muhoho]] at Ngenda, [[Kiambu District]], [[Central Province (Kenya)|Central Province]] in 1933 .{{cite book|title=Kenya Gazette|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aKXDxI823VQC&pg=PA306|accessdate=9 May 2011|date=17 June 1947|pages=306–}}{{cite web|url=https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/evewoman/article/2001241312/kenya-s-first-first-lady-mama-ngina-kenyatta|title=Kenya’s first first lady- Mama Ngina Kenyatta|publisher=The Standard|date=27 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/01/23/why-mama-ngina-met-mzee-moi_c1491998|quote=Mama Ngina was born Ngina Muhoho in 1933, daughter of Chief Muhoho wa Gathecha, in Kiambu District, Central Province.|publisher=The Star Kenya|date=23 January 2017|title=Why Mama Ngina met Mzee Moi}} She married Jomo Kenyatta as his fourth wife in 1951, a union characterised as a "gift" to Kenyatta from his ethnic group, the [[Kikuyu people|Kikuyu]].{{cite book|last=Kiluva-Ndunda|first=Mutindi Mumbua|title=Women's agency and educational policy: the experiences of the women of Kilome, Kenya|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RCH_spGnGXwC&pg=PA56|accessdate=8 May 2011|year=2001|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-0-7914-4761-1|pages=56–}} This became her reference as the "mother of the nation", becoming Mama Ngina Kenyatta, independent Kenya's glamorous [[First Lady]] when Kenyatta became President in 1963. She often accompanied him in public, and had some streets in Nairobi{{cite book|last1=Murray|first1=Martin J.|last2=Myers|first2=Garth Andrew|title=Cities in contemporary Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gkhF3t7D4jsC&pg=PA85|accessdate=8 May 2011|year=2007|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-1-4039-7035-0|pages=85–}} and Mombasa, as well as a Children's Home,{{cite book|last1=Kilbride|first1=Philip|last2=Suda|first2=Collette|last3=Njeru|first3=Enos|title=Street Children in Kenya: Voices of Children in Search of a Childhood|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iMHBsBLFMJUC&pg=PA23|accessdate=8 May 2011|date=September 2001|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-89789-862-1|pages=23–}} named after her. In 1965, she became patron of Kenyan [[Girl Guides|Guiding]].{{cite book|last=Proctor|first=Tammy M.|title=Scouting for girls: a century of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oohUqnIVo-sC&pg=PA140|accessdate=8 May 2011|date=25 September 2009|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-38114-0|pages=140–}} In the 1970s, she and other high-level government officials were allegedly involved in an [[Elephant hunting in Kenya|ivory-smuggling ring]] which transported tusks out of the country in the state private airliner.{{cite book|title=Animal kingdom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oAEdAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=8 May 2011|year=1980|publisher=New York Zoological Society}}{{cite book|last=Wieland|first=Terry|title=A view from a tall hill: Robert Ruark in Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CflNHBquJWAC&pg=PA411|accessdate=6 May 2011|date=25 March 2004|publisher=Down East Enterprise Inc|isbn=978-0-89272-650-9|page=411}}{{cite book|last=Munger|first=Edwin S.|title=Touched by Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=06MMAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=8 May 2011|year=1983|publisher=Castle Press|isbn=978-0-934912-00-6}} A May 1975 edition of ''[[New Scientist]]'' cited her as one of Kenya's "ivory queens" but also asserted they could not be completely certain that these claims were true.{{cite book|title=New Scientist|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zE74f2fU1iwC&pg=PA452|accessdate=8 May 2011|date=22 May 1975|publisher=Reed Business Information|page=452|issn=0262-4079}} However, ''New Scientist'' claimed that there was now documentary proof that at least one member of Kenya's royal family had shipped over six tons of ivory to Red China. Mama Ngina became a Roman Catholic,{{cite book|last=Gibbon|first=Peter|title=Markets, civil society and democracy in Kenya|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xzr3teZOd3AC&pg=PA135|accessdate=9 May 2011|year=1995|publisher=Nordic Africa Institute|isbn=978-91-7106-371-7|pages=135–}} and was known to attend Mass every Sunday in the Catholic mission with some of their children.{{cite book|last=Tablino|first=Paolo|title=Christianity among the nomads: the Catholic communities in Marsabit, Moyale and Samburu districts of Northern Kenya. volume II|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D5WO_giMZbIC&pg=PA37|accessdate=9 May 2011|year=2006|publisher=Paulines Publications Africa|isbn=978-9966-08-120-9|pages=37–}} She also became one of the richest individuals in Kenya, owning plantations, ranches, and hotels.{{cite book|last=Meredith|first=Martin|authorlink=Martin Meredith|title=The fate of Africa: from the hopes of freedom to the heart of despair : a history of fifty years of independence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GyOh8px3CFcC&pg=PA267|accessdate=8 May 2011|date=26 June 2006|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=978-1-58648-398-2|pages=267–}} She currently leads a quiet life in Kenya as a wealthy widow. ==Family== She bore Kenyatta four children: Kristina Wambui (born 1953), [[Uhuru Kenyatta|Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta]] (born 1961), Anna Nyokabi Muthama née Kenyatta (also known as ''Jeni'', born May 1963) and Muhoho Kenyatta (born 1965). Her son Uhuru, the senior Kenyatta's political heir, unsuccessfully ran for president as President Moi's preferred successor in 2002 and is today the Kenyan fourth President. Muhoho Kenyatta runs the family's vast business but lives out of the public limelight. During Jomo Kenyatta's exile at Lodwar and Maralal, Ngina stayed with him, as did their daughters, Jane and Wamboi.{{cite book|author=Johnson Publishing Company|title=Ebony|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oDe4dSJt_6YC&pg=PA82|accessdate=8 May 2011|date=August 1961|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|pages=82–|issn=0012-9011}} Mama Ngina is step-mother to Kenyatta's other three children, two by his first wife and one by the second.{{cite book|author=Johnson Publishing Company|title=Jet|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c8EDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA26|access-date=9 May 2011|date=2 July 1964|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|pages=26–|issn=0021-5996}} [[Monsignor]] George Muhoho, [[Roman Catholic]] [[chaplain]] at [[University of Nairobi]], is one of her brothers.{{cite book|last1=Gitari|first1=David M.|last2=Knighton|first2=Ben|title=Religion and politics in Kenya: essays in honor of a meddlesome priest|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tf7FQS8O3-kC&pg=PA72|accessdate=9 May 2011|date=15 September 2009|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-61487-1|pages=72–}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.npg.org.uk/live/search/portrait.asp?LinkID=mp62833&rNo=0&role=sit Portrait] {{DEFAULTSORT:Kenyatta, Ngina}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:First Ladies of Kenya]] [[Category:Spouses of Prime Ministers of Kenya]] [[Category:Jomo Kenyatta]] [[Category:Kenyan Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Kikuyu people]] [[Category:Kenyatta family|Ngina]]

revision.text:
Captain '''Owen Fiennes Temple Roberts''' [[FRSE]] [[Military Cross|MC]] (1896–1968) was a 20th British astronomer and meteorologist.
==Life== He was born in [[Mauritius]] in 1896 the son of Alfred Temple Roberts (1857-1911) and his wife Susan Charlotte Catherine Fiennes-Clinton (d.1936).<ref>https://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Fiennes-Clinton-6</ref>
In the [[First World War]] he served with the [[Royal Garrison Artillery]] and rose to the rank of Captain, winning the Military Cross.<ref>http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/results/r?_col=200&_cr1=WO+372&_hb=tna&_q=Owen+F+T+Roberts</ref>
After the war he completed his studies at [[Cambridge University]] graduating MA around 1921. He then began lecturing in Astronomy and Meteorology at [[Aberdeen University]].
In 1928 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[Hector Munro Macdonald]], [[James Goodwillie]], [[Ralph Allan Sampson]] and [[Arthur Crichton Mitchell]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref>
He died in [[Leicester]] in 1968.
==Family==
In 1918 he married Ethel S. Fenner in [[Cheltenham]].<ref>https://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Roberts-15057</ref>
==Publications==
*''The Theoretical Scattering of Smoke in a Turbulent Atmosphere'' (1923) *''A Note on Measuring the Gradient Wind'' (1946)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Roberts, Owen Finnes Temple}} [[Category:1896 births]] [[Category:1968 deaths]] [[Category:Mauritian people]] [[Category:British meteorologists]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Recipients of the Military Cross]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Cambridge]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Aberdeen]]
{{UK-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist |name = Pecker Dunne |image = |caption = |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Patrick Dunne | birth_date = {{birth date|1933|4|1|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Castlebar]], [[County Mayo]], Ireland | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|2012|12|19|1933|4|1}}
[[Killimer]], [[County Clare]], {{nowrap|Ireland}} |instrument = [[Vocals]], [[banjo]], [[fiddle]], [[Melodeon (organ)|melodeon]], [[guitar]], [[mandolin]] |genre = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Traditional Irish music|traditional Irish]] |occupation = Musician, songwriter |years_active = 1942–2012 }} '''Patrick "Pecker" Dunne''' (1 April 1933 – 19 December 2012{{cite web|title=Musician Paddy Pecker Dunne dies|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/musician-paddy-pecker-dunne-dies-16252943.html|publisher=[[Belfast Telegraph]]|accessdate=20 December 2012}}) was an [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] musician and [[seanchaí]]. Dunne was born in [[Castlebar]], [[County Mayo]], "in the old [[workhouse|county home]]".{{cite news|title=Folk musician 'Pecker' Dunne has died|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/player/2012/1220/3456507-folk-musician-pecker-dunne-has-died/|accessdate=21 December 2012|newspaper=RTÉ News|date=20 December 2012}} His family were [[Irish Travellers]] originally from [[County Wexford]], where his father was a [[fiddle]] player.{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.ie/~ronolan/pecker.html|title=The Pecker Dunne|date=March 2008|publisher=Ramblinghouse|accessdate=2009-07-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090527062744/http://www.iol.ie/~ronolan/pecker.html|archivedate=2009-05-27|df=}} In ''Parley-poet and Chancer'', an autobiography transcribed by Micheál Ó hAodha (page 21), he stated that he later lived in the [[Dublin]] suburb of [[Drimnagh]]. He was one of Ireland's most noted [[banjo]] players and was also proficient on the fiddle, [[Melodeon (organ)|melodeon]] and guitar, and was among an elite of Traveller musicians.{{cite news |title= Leading Traveller musician and singer-songwriter Patrick (Pecker) Dunne has died, aged 79, in Killimer, Co Clare.|first= Ed|last= Carty|url= http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/cwkfqlgbcwkf/rss2/|newspaper= Irish Examiner|date= 21 December 2012|accessdate=25 December 2012}} Dunne became known to a wide Irish audience from his regular busking at [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] sporting fixtures, particularly in [[Munster]]. Later he played in [[England]], [[France]], [[Australia]] and [[New York City]], where he appeared with [[The Dubliners]]. He also performed alongside [[Richard Harris]] and [[Stephen Rea]] in the 1996 feature film ''[[Trojan Eddie]]''.{{cite news|last= |first=|title=Pecker Dunne passes away|url=http://www.clare.fm/news/pecker-dunne-passes-away|newspaper=Clare FM|date=20 December 2012}} He lived in [[Killimer]], [[County Clare]] with his wife and four children. He died there, aged 79, and is buried in Burrane, near Killimer.{{cite news|last=Deegan|first=Gordon|title='Pecker' Dunne laid to rest in Clare|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/1224/1224328152451.html|accessdate=24 December 2012|newspaper=[[Irish Times]]|date=24 December 2012}}[http://www.coopertoons.com/caricatures/peckerdunne_bio.html "The Pecker" Dunne: The Last of the Traveling People] ==Recordings== * ''Ireland's own Pecker Dunne - the Tinkerman''. 1987 (re-released on CD (Paddyland PLMCD) in 2001) * ''Travellin' People from Ireland''. [[Margaret Barry]] & Pecker Dunne * ''Very Best of Ireland's Legendary Street Singer'' ==References== {{Refbegin}} * ''Parley-Poet and Chanter: An Autobiography, Volume 1'', (2004), by Pecker Dunne & Micheál Ó hAodha, {{ISBN|978-1-899047-13-0}} {{Refend}} {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0242892}} {{Authority control}} {{Irish Travellers}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dunne, Pecker}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Irish people]] [[Category:21st-century Irish people]] [[Category:Irish fiddlers]] [[Category:Irish banjoists]] [[Category:Musicians from County Mayo]] [[Category:People from County Mayo]] [[Category:People from Castlebar]] [[Category:Irish Travellers]] [[Category:Irish buskers]] [[Category:20th-century violinists]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox character | name = Philip J. Fry | series = [[Futurama]] | image = Philip Fry.png | fullname = Philip J. Fry | nickname = Fry | first = "[[Space Pilot 3000]]" | last = ''[[Futurama: Worlds of Tomorrow]]'' | gender = Male | species = Human | alias = Lars Fillmore, Orange Joe, The Mighty One | occupation = [[Courier|Delivery Boy]]/Pilot, Tentacle Pope of Universe Gamma (former) | family = Yancy Fry, Sr. (deceased father)
Mrs. Fry (deceased mother)
[[The Luck of the Fryrish|Yancy Fry, Jr.]] (deceased brother)
Mildred Fry (deceased paternal grandmother)

[[Roswell That Ends Well|Himself]] (grandfather; via [[Time warp (science fiction)|time warp]])
Himself (grandson; via time warp)
Yancy Fry, Jr (grandson; via time warp)
Philip J. Fry II (deceased great-grandson; via time warp)
Turanga Morris (father-in-law)
Turanga Munda (mother-in-law)
Munda's mother (grandmother-in-law)
Munda's grandmother (great-grandmother-in-law; deceased)
Yancy Fry, Jr.'s wife (sister-in-law) | spouse = [[Leela (Futurama)|Turanga Leela]] (wife) | significantother = | children = Yancy Fry, Sr. (son; via time warp)

Kif's Offspring (stepchildren) | relatives =Philip J. Fry II (deceased nephew)

Igner (distant nephew) | voice = [[Billy West]] | lbl21 = Place of Origin | data21 = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] }} '''Philip J. Fry''', commonly known simply by his surname '''Fry''', is a [[fictional character]] and the [[protagonist]] of the [[animated sitcom]] ''[[Futurama]]''. He is voiced by [[Billy West]] using a version of his own voice as he sounded when he was 25.{{cite news |author= |work=[[Fresh Air]] |title=Billy West: The Many (Cartoon) Voices In His Head |url=https://www.npr.org/2010/07/15/128490848/billy-west-the-many-cartoon-voices-in-his-head |quote='His voice is basically what I sounded like when I was 25. Kinda plain vanilla. I had nothing special about my voice, really. And I just thought, 'Well, I know that character so well.' ... [T]o try to do someone else's real voice is kind of tough.'|publisher=[[National Public Radio]] |date=July 15, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-05 }} He is a [[slacker]] [[delivery boy]] from the 20th century who becomes [[cryogenics|cryogenically frozen]] and reawakens in the 30th century to become a delivery boy there with an [[intergalactic travel|intergalactic]] delivery company run by his 30th great nephew, [[Professor Farnsworth|Professor Hubert J. Farnsworth]]. He is the best friend and roommate of [[Bender (Futurama)|Bender]] and the boyfriend and later husband of [[Leela (Futurama)|Turanga Leela]]. He is the father of Yancy Fry, Sr. (due to an affair with his soon-to-be paternal grandmother) and in comic only, Elena Fry as well as the stepfather of Kif's Offspring (due to Kif's pregnancy and Leela's accident motherhood). ==Character overview== Born in the 20th century in [[New York City]], Fry is depicted as an unintelligent manchild in his 20s.Leela gives Fry's age in the first season episode "[[My Three Suns]]". The episode "[[The Luck of the Fryrish]]" seems to imply he was 25 at the time of his freezing.At the beginning of the episode, a flashback goes back to his birth; the year is implied to be 1969 as a radio broadcast is heard with the [[New York Mets]] winning the [[1969 World Series|World Series]]. He is a [[pizza delivery]] boy who, during the last few seconds of the year 1999, falls into a [[cryogenics|cryogenic]] tank while delivering a pizza to Applied Cryogenics. He remains frozen until the last day of the year 2999. He then meets the one-eyed cryogenics counselor and his-soon-to-be wife, [[Leela (Futurama)|Leela]] and the cigar-smoking, [[alcoholic]], [[kleptomania]]c robot [[Bender (Futurama)|Bender]]. Together, they are employed by Fry's distant nephew, the senile and demented old scientist [[Professor Farnsworth]], as the crew of his delivery company Planet Express. Fry's parents are Yancy Fry, Sr., a strict [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] who believes in [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]], and Sherri Fry (née Gleisner), an inattentive chain smoker and avid [[New York Mets]] fan. It is later revealed that Fry's family on his father's side is from [[New Mexico]]. In the past Fry had an older brother named Yancy; a dog named [[Jurassic Bark|Seymour]]; and a girlfriend named Michelle (who dumped him in the first episode, "[[Space Pilot 3000]]", just before he was frozen). Fry had a lifelong [[sibling rivalry]] with his older brother Yancy, due to Fry's perception that Yancy steals everything from him and vice versa. After dropping out of [[Coney Island]] Community College, he then got a job as a delivery boy at Panucci's Pizza. Depictions of Fry's family in early episodes showed them as extremely dysfunctional, with a neglectful mother and borderline-abusive father. Later seasons, however, depicted them as much closer and, while still dysfunctional, more loving and attentive, with Fry's father treating him harshly to ensure he grew up tough. He survived a heart attack. ===Personality and abilities=== Fry is characterized as simple, gullible, sweet, yet immature. Fry regards Bender as his closest friend. He also has strong feelings for Leela, although he lacks the intelligence required for articulating his emotions; thus, for most of the series his love remains (sometimes coldly) [[Unrequited love|unrequited]], though not entirely without hope. She does occasionally return his interest throughout the series, and in the movie ''[[Futurama: Into the Wild Green Yonder|Into the Wild Green Yonder]]'' she admits to loving him back. At the end of that film, they are seen sharing a kiss as they enter a wormhole, and subsequently begin dating. Despite his low intelligence, Fry is very kind-hearted, as he often goes out of his way to help his friends, even if he is sometimes oblivious to their problems. He tolerates all of his friends' quirks and is notable as the only staff member who accepts the ship's doctor, [[Zoidberg]]. Although at times lacking in self-awareness, Fry always tries to do the right thing and fix his mistakes. Fry has shown remarkable skill playing video games, (even mastering the 31st-century's version on the Internet), and in "[[Bender Should Not Be Allowed on TV]]" is seen successfully playing a game despite not looking at the screen. This skill carries over to using Planet Express Ship's laser gun. Fry has also exhibited remarkable bravery and self-sacrifice on occasion and has even displayed flashes of stagnant intelligence. Also, despite his laziness and clumsiness, Fry has proved to be a competent fighter in "[[Law and Oracle]]" and "[[Fun on a Bun]]", the latter episode showing that Fry is skilled enough to hold his own against Leela in direct physical combat. He has also survived a heart attack intentionally caused by his best friend Bender. In the episode "[[The Why of Fry]]", Leela's seemingly oblivious pet [[Nibbler (Futurama)|Nibbler]] reveals himself as the reason for Fry's freezing; because Fry lacks the [[Delta wave|Delta brainwave]]. Due to a time-travel incident in "[[Roswell That Ends Well]]", he is his own grandfather. He can withstand the intellect-draining onslaught of the evil [[Brainspawn]] and is immune to the Dark One's mind-reading in ''[[Futurama: Into the Wild Green Yonder|Into the Wild Green Yonder]]'' as well as the mind-controlling power of the Hypnotoad. Nibbler's race, the Nibblonians, dub him "The Mighty One". Through prediction (on the eve of 1999, as the Nibblonians lack the ability to travel through time), they guessed that Fry would be the one to save the world from the evil Brainspawn. Because his natural lifespan would not extend to the right millennium, however, Nibbler is sent to make the aforementioned delivery call to push an unsuspecting Fry into the cryogenic tube, to re-emerge December 31, 2999. In several episodes, he feels nostalgic for the 20th century, and tries to convince his coworkers how good it was back then. ===Love life=== ====Leela==== Leela is Fry's main love interest, and his love for her provides a major plot line throughout the series. Fry first begins to show a serious interest in her from the second season onwards, although she constantly turns him down for other dates due to his immaturity, though she says that she loves his boyish charm. Leela initially sees Fry as a friend and nothing more, but deeper affection for him appears occasionally, such as on the numerous occasions when he risks his life for hers ("[[Love and Rocket]]", "[[The Sting (Futurama)|The Sting]]", "[[Lrrreconcilable Ndndifferences]]"). Fry's feelings for Leela are openly displayed throughout the series. In "The Sting", Fry throws himself in front of a baby Queen Bee to protect Leela, resulting in the bee's stinger completely penetrating his torso. In "Love and Rocket", upon noticing that Leela's oxygen tank was running on 'critical', he attaches her oxygen tube to his tank, giving her his oxygen and almost asphyxiating himself. In "[[Parasites Lost]]", Fry becomes infected with symbiotic "parasites" which enhance his muscles and intelligence, allowing him to attract Leela's romantic attention. However, fearing that Leela was attracted to him only for his worms, he rids himself of them in a failed bid to begin a genuine relationship. In "[[Time Keeps on Slippin']]", Fry moves the stars to write a love note to Leela, but the message is blown up before she can read it. In the final episode of the initial run, "[[The Devil's Hands are Idle Playthings]]", Fry trades hands with the Robot Devil in order to compose an opera about Leela in which they fall in love. When Fry returns the Robot Devil's hands to prevent him from forcing Leela to marry him, the opera deteriorates, causing the audience to leave. Fry sadly walks off the stage. Leela is the only one who remains behind, asking Fry not to stop because she wants to hear how it ends. He picks up his holophonor and composes a crude ending in which the stage-Fry and stage-Leela share a single kiss. In the film ''[[Futurama: Bender's Big Score]]'' Leela falls in love with a seemingly perfect man, Lars, and they soon become engaged. However, Lars leaves Leela on her wedding day explaining later that as a time paradox he is doomed, and that he wouldn't marry her only to have her lose him soon after. Through this he then reveals that he is in fact the time paradox of Fry, who had undergone physical changes due to an explosion and become more mature through 12 years of age and experience. At the end of the film ''[[Futurama: Into the Wild Green Yonder]]'', Leela openly admits to loving Fry, and they commence an openly romantic relationship from the episode "[[Rebirth (Futurama)|Rebirth]]" onwards. In "[[The Prisoner of Benda]]" they have "sex", albeit in differing bodies. The on-again, off again nature of their relationship causes Leela to leave Planet Express and Fry in "[[Overclockwise]]", however by the end of the episode, Leela returns to Planet Express and seemingly reunites with Fry. Bender reveals to both Fry and Leela their "ultimate fate" that he learned while he was overclocked. The audience is never shown the contents, but through their facial expressions it is clear that while the journey for them may be bumpy, Fry and Leela will ultimately end up happy. In later episodes, such as "[[The Butterjunk Effect]]" and "[[Fun on a Bun]]", Fry and Leela are shown to be in a relationship, though the events of the series precipitate frequent arguments and breakups. These issues are usually resolved within the episode, leaving Fry and Leela still together at the end. During the series finale "[[Meanwhile (Futurama)|Meanwhile]]", Fry decides that it is time for him to propose to Leela. Wanting the moment of his proposal to last longer, he steals Professor Farnsworth's time machine remote that turns back time every 10 seconds. When Leela is late, he thinks she has rejected him and attempts suicide by jumping off the building; he sees her arriving just in time, however, and presses the reset button over and over again to keep from hitting the ground. He accidentally breaks the remote and freezes time, leaving himself and Leela as the only unfrozen beings in the universe. Leela accepts Fry's proposal, and they have a long, happy marriage. The Professor shows up during one of their anniversaries and repairs the time machine, but informs them it will reset their lives, leaving them with no memory of the lifetime they spent together. Fry asks Leela if she wants to go around again with him, and she replies that she does. But they are apparently still married in the video game ''[[Futurama: Worlds of Tomorrow]]''.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} ====Michelle==== Michelle (voiced by [[Kath Soucie]] in the first appearance, [[Sarah Silverman]] in the second appearance) is Fry's on-and-off girlfriend from the 20th century. Shortly before Fry is frozen, she dumps him for a man named Constantine (called Charles in "[[The Cryonic Woman]]"), whom she later marries. They eventually split up, and she decides to freeze herself to try again in the distant future. She wakes up in 3002, meets Fry again, and restarts her relationship with him. However, she fails to fit into the 31st-century life to which Fry has become so accustomed, and so asks him to freeze himself with her for another thousand years. This plan fails, as does the rekindled relationship, so Fry leaves her. She later is shown in a limousine with the recently unfrozen [[Pauly Shore]]. In the episode "[[Proposition Infinity]]", she is again shown with Pauly Shore, and the implication is that they are now married. ====Amy Wong==== During a trip on the luxury [[starship|starliner]] ''Titanic'', [[Amy Wong]] passes Fry off as her boyfriend to avoid being set up by her parents with an unattractive potential husband. Unfortunately, [[Leela (Futurama)|Leela]] was also passing Fry off as her fake fiancé to ward off the attentions of [[Zapp Brannigan]]. Potential embarrassment is averted by catastrophic damage to the ship, and Amy wins the battle of the bogus boyfriends. In "[[Put Your Head on My Shoulders]]", Fry and Amy are trapped together in a desert on [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]] and realize they have a lot in common. While being towed to the nearest gas station to refuel, they have sex in the car. They continue the relationship back home, but Fry intends to end it the day before [[Valentine's Day]] because he feels that they are spending too much time together. An accident ends with Fry's head being temporarily attached to Amy's body, causing much tension due to Fry's decision to break up and Amy's subsequent date, forcing Leela to step in and distract Amy's date to save Fry from an awkward situation. Despite their break-up, they remain good friends. ==Production== [[File:Billy West by Gage Skidmore 2.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Billy West provides the voice of Fry.]] Although [[Billy West]] stated in an interview that the name "Philip" was given to Fry by [[Matt Groening]] as a homage to the late [[Phil Hartman]], for whom the role of [[Zapp Brannigan]] was created,{{cite web|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2006/06/15/billy-west-the-tv-squad-interview/|title=Billy West: The TV Squad Interview|accessdate=2007-06-09|date=2006-06-15|author=Joel Keller|publisher=TV Squad.com}} Groening said during the 2013 Futurama panel at the [[San Diego Comic-Con]] that Fry was in fact named after Groening's father, Homer Phillip Groening,{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/video-clips/iqfydq/futurama-comic-con-2013---futurama-panel|title=Comic-Con 2013 - Futurama Panel|accessdate=2014-02-03|date=2013-07-18|publisher=ComedyCentral.com}} who was also the namesake for [[Homer Simpson]]. According to Groening, Fry's character developed over time while still keeping his qualities as a loser and the characteristics which writers hoped would make him appeal to the target young male audience. Fry's character is essentially a bungling, stubborn slob with a heart of gold who cannot get ahead in the world, but still has a slight glimmer of hope.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CEFDF173EF931A15754C0A96F958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=2| title=Bringing an Alien And a Robot to Life; The Gestation of the Simpsons' Heirs| author=Sterngold, James|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]| date=1999-07-22| accessdate=2008-06-20}} Fry's trademark outfit - a red [[windbreaker]] jacket, white [[t-shirt]] and blue [[jeans]] - is based on [[James Dean]]'s outfit from ''[[Rebel Without a Cause]]''.{{cite video|people=Cohen, David X.; Groening, Matt; Moore, Rich; Vanzo, Gregg; DiMaggio, John|date=2002|title=Futurama: Volume One DVD commentary for the episode "[[Space Pilot 3000]]"|medium=DVD|publisher=20th Century Fox|quote=Matt Groening: Oh and, Fry's wearing James Dean's outfit in Rebel Without a Cause.}} Fry is voiced by Billy West, who also voices [[Zoidberg|Doctor Zoidberg]], [[Professor Farnsworth|Hubert J. Farnsworth]] and various other characters in the series. Although West auditioned for the part, it was originally given to [[Charlie Schlatter]];{{cite news|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/24/futurama-rama-welcome-back-to-the-world-of-tomorrow/| title=‘Futurama’-Rama: Welcome Back to the World of Tomorrow| author=[[Dave Itzkoff|Itzkoff, Dave]]|newspaper=The New York Times| date=2010-06-24| accessdate=2010-07-08}} however, after a casting change, West was offered the job. The voice West uses for Fry has been described as that of a "generic Saturday-morning good guy".{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D04EED71730F935A15750C0A96F958260| title=A Feeling We're Not in Springfield . . .| author=Wertheimer, Ron|newspaper=The New York Times| quote=Originally I had auditioned for Dr. Zoidberg, Bender, the Professor and Fry. But I didn't get Fry — it went to Charlie Schlatter, who's a heck of an actor and a great voice guy, but they just changed plans. They said to me, 'Fry’s 25, so bear that in mind.' It became a high-pitched version of me, trying to remember the dumb innocence of being 25. At that age I had no idea where I was going, I was working for U-Haul shoveling dirt out of trucks, I was washing dishes at nursing homes. I always thought I had this whiny, complaining voice — this plain vanilla voice, but I guess if you're in neutral, you can go anywhere | date=1999-03-26| accessdate=2008-06-19}} West admits that he intentionally made Fry's sound similar to his own, claiming that keeping the "cartoony" aspects out of it would make it harder for someone else to imitate the same voice. He notes that the voice is higher than his own and that he tried to duplicate the voice he had at age 25, which he describes as "this whiny, complaining voice — this plain vanilla voice". West also voices Lars Fillmore in ''[[Futurama: Bender's Big Score]]'', who is a time travel duplicate of Fry with an injured [[larynx]], and therefore, a slightly altered voice. The producers initially considered having a different [[voice actor]] do Lars' voice in order to keep viewers from guessing his true identity, but ultimately decided it would not make sense if anyone besides West did the voice.This is mentioned on the DVD commentary of ''Bender's Big Score''. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Futurama|Fictional characters}} *[http://theinfosphere.org/Philip_J._Fry Philip J. Fry] at The Infosphere: The Futurama Wiki {{Wikinews|Billy West, voice of Ren and Stimpy, Futurama, on the rough start that shaped his life}} {{Wikiquote}} {{Futurama}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fry, Philip J.}} [[Category:Futurama characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters from New York City]] [[Category:Fictional cryonically preserved characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters who have made pacts with devils]] [[Category:Fictional war veterans]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1999]] [[Category:Fictional American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Fictional American people of German descent]] [[Category:Fictional American people of English descent]] [[Category:Fictional characters involved in incest]] [[Category:Fictional offspring of incestuous relationships]] [[Category:Fictional attempted suicides]] [[Category:Male characters in animation]] [[cs:Seznam hlavních postav ve Futuramě#Philip J. Fry]]

'''Craig Richard Coley''' (born 1947) was convicted of a double murder in Los Angeles, California and spent 39 years in jail before he was pardoned in 2017 because advanced DNA tests not available at his original trial showed he was innocent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5035906/craig-richard-coley-wrongly-convicted/|title=Man Wrongfully Convicted of 1978 Murder Is Freed From Prison|last=Cooper|first=Jonathan J.|date=2017-11-23|website=Time|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5121351/Man-wrongfully-jailed-39-years-celebrates-Thanksgiving.html|title=Man wrongfully jailed for 39 years celebrates with cop who freed him|last=Malm|first=Sara|date=2017-11-27|work=Daily Mail Online|access-date=2018-01-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
On November 11th 1978 24-year-old Rhonda Wicht and her 4-year-old son, Donald Wicht, were found dead in her apartment in Simi Valley, a suburb of Los Angeles, California.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=5239|title=Craig Coley|last=|first=|date=2017-12-04|website=Michigan State University College of Law - National Registry of Exonerations|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref> Donald Wicht had been suffocated and Rhonda Wicht had been raped, beaten and strangled. The police suspected Coley was the murderer because he had been Rhonda Wicht's boyfriend for two years and the couple had recently broken up.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-simi-pardon-evidence-20171124-story.html|title=How evidence once thought destroyed helped free a man after 39 years behind bars for murder he didn't commit|last=Nelson|first=Laura J.|date=2017-11-24|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-11-26|last2=Tchekmedyian|first2=Alene|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
Coley, a restaurant night manager who had previously served in the US navy including three deployments to Vietnam in an aircraft carrier,<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/man-wrongly-jailed-almost-40-years-gets-2m-payout-says-it-cant-make-lost-time-1661928|title=Man wrongly jailed for almost 40 years gets $2m payout - but says it can't make up for lost time|last=Baird|first=Roger|date=2018-02-16|work=International Business Times UK|access-date=2018-02-17|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nvf.org/wrongfully-convicted-veteran-free/|title=Wrongfully Convicted Veteran Free After 39 Years Behind Bars|last=Morgan|first=Bill|date=2017-12-06|work=National Veterans Foundation|access-date=2018-01-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> was arrested the same day as the murders and charged with the double murder. The first trial resulted in a hung jury. The second trial in 1980 led to his conviction<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/13866066/la_times_130_80_p_53/|title=Jury recommends prison for murderer|last=|first=|date=1969-12-31|work=LA Times|access-date=2018-01-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|page=|pages=53|subscription=Y}}</ref> and he was sentenced to life imprisonment without parole.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailynews.com/2017/11/23/man-freed-decades-after-double-killing-that-rocked-simi-valley/|title=Man freed decades after double killing that rocked Simi Valley|last=Cooper|first=Jonathan J.|date=2017-11-23|work=Los Angeles Daily News|access-date=2018-01-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
After Coley lost his final appeal to his conviction, the judge ordered all evidence to be destroyed.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.vcstar.com/story/news/local/communities/simi-valley/2017/11/24/wrongly-convicted-man-spends-thanksgiving-free-cop-who-fought-his-release/893536001/|title=Wrongly convicted Craig Coley spends Thanksgiving free with the cop who fought for his release|last=Diskin|first=Megan|date=2017-11-24|work=Ventura County Star|access-date=2018-01-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
Michael Bender, a serving Detective with Simi Valley Police Department, started to re-investigate Coley's case in 1989 and discovered there were problems with the case. Until his death, Coley's father, a retired police officer, had been trying to free his son.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/calif-man-wrongfully-jailed-1978-double-homicide-freed-article-1.3654804|title=Calif. man wrongfully jailed for 1978 double homicide freed|last=Schladebeek|first=Jessica|date=2017-11-24|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2017-11-26|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> Simi Valley Police Chief Dave Livinstone PhD, requested a new investigation by Cold Case Detecitve Dan Swanson. Det. Swanson located the missing evidence and new DNA tests not available at the original trial showed there was no trace of Coley's DNA on the evidence material, but there was the DNA of other people.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.augsburger-allgemeine.de/panorama/Wieder-frei-nach-39-Jahren-im-Gefaengnis-id43354211.html|title=Wieder frei nach 39 Jahren im Gefängnis|last=Spang|first=Thomas|date=2017-11-27|work=Augsburger Allgemeine|access-date=2018-01-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=de|trans-title=Free again after 39 years in prison}}</ref> Investigators also disproved the testimony of a witness from the original trial who claimed to have seen Coley at the scene of the crime.<ref name=":2" /> In a report to the local police, three former and current police officers testified that the detective at the time of Coley's trial had “mishandled the investigation or framed Mr. Coley.” The local prosecutor felt the original detectives decided Coley was guilty too quickly (that they were victims of "tunnel vision").<ref name=":0" />
California governor Jerry Brown pardoned Coley on 22 November 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.ca.gov/docs/Craig_Coley_Pardon.pdf|title=Pardon - Crag Richard Coley|last=Brown|first=Edmund G.|date=2017-11-22|website=Executive Department, State of California|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref> because the evidence showed he was innocent of the murders.<ref name=":0" /> In February 2018, the California Victims Compensation Board awarded Coley almost $2 million in compensation for his wrongful imprisonment for almost 40 years.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":1" />
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Coley, Richard}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People wrongfully convicted of murder]] [[Category:People from California]] [[Category:Overturned convictions in the United States]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]]
