{{Infobox person | name = Rose Akol | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|11|27|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Bukedea District]], [[Uganda]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater =[[Makerere University Business School]]
{{small|([[Master of Business Administration]] in accounting and finance)}} | occupation = Accountant and politician | years_active = 1989 — present | nationality = [[Uganda]]n | citizenship = Uganda | residence = [[Kampala]], Uganda | known_for = Politics | networth = | home_town = [[Bukedea]] | title = Minister of Internal Affairs | spouse = }} '''Rose Akol Okullu''', commonly known as '''Rose Akol''' (born 27 November 1964), is a [[Uganda]]n accountant and politician. She was appointed as Minister of Internal Affairs on 16 November 2015.{{cite web | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/675772-akol-appointed-internal-affairs-minister.html | title=Akol appointed internal affairs minister | last=Vision Reporter | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | location=Kampala | date=16 November 2015 | accessdate=17 November 2015}} She is expected to assume office following confirmation by the [[Parliament of Uganda]]. She is also an elected member of parliament as [[Bukedea District]]'s women's representative.{{cite web | url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201511162873.html | title=Uganda:Akol Okullu Rose Appointed Internal Affairs Minister | last=The Observer | newspaper=[[The Observer (Uganda)]] via [[AllAfrica.com]] | location=Kampala | date=16 November 2015 | accessdate=17 November 2015}} ==Background and education== She was born in Bukedea District, and attended [[Ngora High School]].{{cite web | url=http://theinvestigatornews.com/2015/11/museveni-replaces-fallen-gen-aronda-nyakairima-with-little-known-mp-rose-akol-as-aging-kirunda-kivejinja-bounces-back/ | title=Museveni Replaces Fallen Gen Aronda Nyakairima with ‘Little Known’ MP Rose Akol as Aging Kirunda Kivejinja Bounces Back | last=Investigator Reporter | newspaper=The Investigator News | location=Kampala | date=16 November 2015 | accessdate=23 September 2016}} She holds a [[Masters in Business Administration]] degree in finance and accounting, awarded in 2004 by the [[Makerere University Business School]]. ==Work experience== She started her career in 1989 as an assistant accountant at the Uganda Export Promotions Council, serving in that position until 1990. From 1990 until 1993, she served as an accountant at the Karamoja Development Agency. From 1994 until 2000, she was a senior internal auditor at the [[Uganda Airlines|Uganda Airlines Corporation]]. From 2003 until 2006, she served as the head of internal audit at the Joint Clinical Research Centre. She concurrently served as an accountant at the [[East African Airlines]]. In 2006, she entered elective parliamentary politics by winning the seat of Bukedea District woman's representative. She was re-elected in 2011.{{cite web | url=http://www.parliament.go.ug/mpdata/mps.hei?p=f&n=t&details=t&j=523&const=Woman+Representative&dist_id=84&distname=Bukedea | accessdate=17 November 2015 | title=Profile of Mrs. Akol Rose Okullu, Woman Representative for Bukedea District | last=POU | publisher=[[Parliament of Uganda]] (POU) | location=Kampala | date=17 November 2015}} ==Personal details== Rose Akol is married. She is of the [[Roman Catholic]] faith. She is a member of the [[National Resistance Movement]] political party. ==See also== * [[Teso sub-region]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.parliament.go.ug/new/ Website of the Parliament of Uganda] {{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Akol, Rose}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Makerere University Business School alumni]] [[Category:Government ministers of Uganda]] [[Category:People from Bukedea District]] [[Category:Itesot people]] [[Category:People from Eastern Region, Uganda]] [[Category:People from Teso sub-region]] [[Category:Ugandan accountants]] [[Category:Women accountants]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]] [[Category:Female interior ministers]] [[Category:Women government ministers of Uganda]]

revision.text:
'''Sherron Watkins''' (born August 28, 1959) is an [[United States|American]] former Vice President of [[Corporate development|Corporate Development]] at the [[Enron|Enron Corporation]]. Watkins was called to testify before committees of the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] and [[United States Senate|Senate]] at the beginning of 2002, primarily about her warnings to Enron's then-CEO Kenneth Lay about accounting irregularities in the financial statements.<ref> {{cite news|last=Stout|first=David|date=2012-02-14|title=Enron Official Says She Warned Lay About Financial Irregularities|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/02/14/business/enron-official-says-she-warned-lay-about-financial-irregularities.html|work=New York Times|location=New York|access-date=2002-02-15}}</ref>
In August 2001, Watkins alerted then-Enron [[CEO]] [[Kenneth Lay]] of [[accounting]] irregularities in [[financial report]]s. However, Watkins has been criticized for not reporting the [[fraud]] to government authorities and not speaking up publicly sooner about her concerns, as her memo did not reach the public until five months after it was written.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ackman|first=Dan|title=Sherron Watkins Had Whistle But Blew It|url=https://www.forbes.com/2002/02/14/0214watkins.html|publisher=Forbes Magazine|website = Forbes.com|date = 2002-02-14|accessdate = 2013-08-11}}</ref> Ms. Watkins was represented by Houston attorney [[Philip H. Hilder]].
Watkins was selected as one of three "[[Time Magazine Person of the Year|Persons of the Year]] 2002" by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. (The two other [[whistleblower]]s who joined her as "People of the Year" were [[Cynthia Cooper (accountant)|Cynthia Cooper]] of [[WorldCom]] and [[Coleen Rowley]] of the [[FBI]].)
==Early life and education== Watkins was born in [[Tomball, Texas]]. Watkins holds a [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] (with honors) from the [[University of Texas]], where she was a member of [[Alpha Chi Omega]] sorority,<ref>{{cite web| url =http://www.alphachiomega.org/about_axo/notable_alumnae.asp| title =About ΑΧΩ Notable Alumnae| publisher =Alpha Chi Omega| accessdate =2007-09-20| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071223050954/http://www.alphachiomega.org/about_axo/notable_alumnae.asp| archivedate =2007-12-23| df =}}</ref> and a Masters of Professional Accounting, also from the [[McCombs School of Business]]. Watkins is a [[Certified Public Accountant]].
==Career== Watkins began her career in 1982 at [[Arthur Andersen]] as an auditor. She spent 8 years at Andersen in both the [[Houston]] and [[Manhattan|New York]] offices. She joined New York-based [[Metallgesellschaft|MG Trade Finance]] in 1990 to manage their portfolio of commodity-backed finance assets until October 1993.
She joined Enron in 1993, and departed in November 2002. Since then, Watkins has been giving speeches at colleges and management congresses.
In 2004, she released a book about her experiences at Enron and the problems of US corporate culture, ''Power Failure: The Inside Story of the Collapse of Enron''.
==Books== *[[Mimi Swartz]] with Sherron Watkins: ''[[Power Failure. The Inside Story of The Collapse of Enron]]'', {{ISBN|0-385-50787-9}} (March 2003)
==Film== * ''[[Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room]]''. 2005. [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0413845/ IMDB] Includes personal interviews with Sherron Watkins. * ''[[The Crooked E: The Unshredded Truth About Enron]]''. 2003. Portrayed as a staff accountant who nervously alerts [[Kenneth Lay|Lay]] of the misstatements.
==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.allbusiness.com/educational-services/business-schools-computer/290768-1.html | title=Interview with Sherron Watkins | publisher=Journal of Leadership & Organizational Studies }}
==External links== *[http://www.sherronwatkins.com/sherronwatkins/Welcome_to_SherronWatkins.com.html SherronWatkins.com] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040422140914/http://www.itmweb.com/f012002.htm Sherron Watkins email to Enron Chairman Kenneth Lay, August 2001]
{{Time Persons of the Year 2001-2025}}
{{Authority control}}

[[Image:Provincetown memorial to Lost Pilgrims.JPG|thumb|right|300px|[[Provincetown, Massachusetts]], memorial to Pilgrims who died on board the ''Mayflower'' in Nov./Dec. 1620]]
'''William Butten''' was a young [[indentured servant]] of [[Samuel Fuller (Pilgrim)|Samuel Fuller]], a long-time leader of the [[Leiden]] Church. Butten died during the voyage of the ''[[Mayflower]]'' while traveling with Fuller, who had been appointed doctor for the group. At that time, children and young men were routinely rounded up from the streets of London or taken from poor families receiving church relief to be used as laborers in the colonies.<ref name="Morison">Morison & Commager, ''The Growth of the American Republic, Virginia, 1618-1622'' (in H.S. vol. 1,(4th Ed., New York, 1950), p.40</ref><ref>R.C. Johnson, ''The Transportation of Vagrant Children from London to Reinmuth'' (Ed.), Early Stuart Studies: Essays in Honor of David Harris Willson, (Minneapolis: 1970)</ref> Butten was sick the entire voyage and died at sea when near the coast of New England.
==''Mayflower'' Voyage== The ''Mayflower'' departed [[Plymouth]], England, on September 6/16, 1620. The small, 100-foot ship had 102 passengers and a crew of about 30-40 in extremely cramped conditions. By the second month out, the ship was being buffeted by strong westerly gales, causing the ship's timbers to be badly shaken with caulking failing to keep out sea water, and with passengers, even in their berths, lying wet and ill. This, combined with a lack of proper rations and unsanitary conditions for several months, attributed to what would be fatal for many, especially the majority of women and children. On the way there were two deaths, a crew member and a passenger, but the worst was yet to come after arriving at their destination when, in the space of several months, almost half the passengers perished in cold, harsh, unfamiliar New England winter.<ref name= "Stratton p. 413">Eugene Aubrey Stratton, ''Plymouth Colony: Its History and People, 1620-1691,'' (Salt Lake City: Ancestry Publishing, 1986), p. 413</ref>
On November 9/19, 1620, after about three months at sea, including a month of delays in England, they spotted land, which was Cape Cod. And after several days of trying to get south to their planned destination of the [[Colony of Virginia]], strong winter seas forced them to return to the harbor at [[Cape Cod]] hook, where they anchored on November 11/21. The [[Mayflower Compact]] was signed that day. There were forty-one of the adult males, including the servants, who signed the Compact.<ref name= "Stratton p. 413"/><ref>George Ernest Bowman, '' The Mayflower Compact and its signers'', (Boston: Massachusetts Society of ''Mayflower'' Descendants, 1920), Photocopies of the 1622, 1646 and 1669 versions of the document, pp. 7-19.</ref>
==Parentage== William Butten's parentage is a mystery. His name is of an ancient French heritage introduced in England after Norman Conquest.<ref>Internet Archives Surname Database''[http://www.surnamedb.com/Surname/Button'']''</ref> He seemed to be a long-time member of the Leiden congregation and therefore was probably one of the [[Separatism|Separatists]]. Upon the death of his father, his mother being too poor to support him, he became an [[indentured servant]].<ref>Donald F. Harris, PhD., ''The Mayflower Descendant'', (July 1993), vol. 43 no. 2 p.124</ref><ref name="Morison"/> One theory is that he may have been the son of Robert Butten and baptized Austerfield 12 February 1598.<ref>William Bradford, ''History of Plymouth Plantation by William Bradford, the second Governor of Plymouth'', (Boston: 1856, Not in copyright), p. 76</ref><ref>Charles Edward Banks, ''Original Narratives of Early American History'', (New York: Grafton Press, 1929), p. 94</ref> Another version is that his family were members of the Separatist Community in [[Worksop]], [[Nottinghamshire]] and was baptized March 13, 1605 there, near [[William Bradford (Plymouth governor)|William Bradford]] and other Separatists.
Butten is memorialized on the ''Mayflower'' Passengers Who Died at Sea Memorial.<ref>Memorial of William Butten ''Mayflower'' passengers who died at sea memorial [http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=cr&CRid=2190420]</ref>
